Tim, Walter Cronkite's enthusiasm for space exploration was a unique and puzzling incongruity of character in an otherwise sober and careful television journalist. He lacked David Brinkley's dry wit, but he set the standard for decisions regarding the type of news that would be investigated and reported, and the manner in which it was presented. I imagine you've seen Cronkite's real-time commentaries on Gemini and Apollo flights, but I doubt you've seen more than short clips from his nightly news broadcasts - which I saw in real time throughout the 1960s, 1970s, and very early 1980s. He was a different man on those nightly 30-minute broadcasts, and certainly in the 1970s, he understood those broadcasts as one of the great responsibilities of his time, since the world would take his words as unimpeachable and factual recitation of the most important matters of the day. If you go to the Moon, you will gain financially more than Walter Cronkite ever did, as a percentage of income pre- and post-Space Race. I believe your zeal for space-related developments is probably greater even than Cronkite's, but I don't see your commitment as being driven by journalistic standards, as Cronkite's unquestionably was. The comparison, then, does not stand up to scrutiny, at least for me. But Cronkite was the news broadcaster who most emoted on space-related matters, so perhaps you can get away with the comparison. But please keep in mind, the major reason CBS gave Cronkite the first chair in reporting space news was that he had demonstrated mastery of news reporting in general. News was not a money-making venture back then. Certainly it was a consideration, but it was understood by the networks more as a *responsibility*. The networks maintained bureaus in all of the major world capitals, and they lost money on most of them, but they were ethically bound to maintain those bureaus. Now the networks maintain only a handful of bureaus and rely almost exclusively on "freelance" journalists living on Raman noodles, because it saves money. Cronkite lived and worked in a very different time. Keep in mind that his careful calculations and sober sentiments informed even his space reporting. Now that you've made this awkward comparison, perhaps you would do yourself and your followers a service by researching Cronkite's WWII and 1950s reporting, and his famous work on the Vietnam War, and become a bit humbled by this unequaled giant of American journalism - and then reporting on what you find. You will not only be humbled into the dust, but you may become a better reporter of space news by learning from the master. PM 2021

I'm old enough to remember Walter Cronkite's reaction to Neil Armstrong's first steps on the moon. He shook his head in amazement, rubbed his hands excitedly, and the look in his eyes made us connect with the child inside of all of us -- awestruck with the wonder of what we were witnessing.

Tim Dodd, you say you want to be this generation's Walter Cronkite -- dude, you already ARE, at least when it comes to space. I've had a lifelong fascination with the subject and there is no one else who comes close. Your interviews are top notch, (best chat(s) with Elon that anyone has ever done imho) your technical breakdowns like full flow rocket engines are well-researched and entertaining, and now you have set up shop at Starbase, for now the front row to the future.

Hell, why not be part of that future? I really hope you get to go to space someday. A great New Frontier is there to experienced and I'm probably too old to get there someday myself, but in the meantime there is no one else I'd rather see there than you. You are like so many of us, a huge geek following his dreams -- and if they get you in orbit, or maybe even all the way to the moon and beyond, it will be like we are all there with you. Years of hard work have put you in the top tier of the most deserving candidates to go -- and knowing you know the substantial risks and have shared your trepidation but still you throw your hat in the ring?

Walter Cronkite was the face and voice of everything important for me in the world growing up. Born in Jan of 1950 I was eyewitness to so much unbelievable history. Sputnik, Explorer, Kennedy ”We choose to go to the moon” speech at Rice university... Mercury, Redstone, the Vanguard failures and Atlas triumphs. Alan’s highs, and Gus’s lows. John’s orbit and Ed White with his Space Walk and mobility “pistol”. These were my hopes and heroes as I grew up. There was a lot of sadness along the way to Apollo and the moon as well. Thankfully the thrill of a Christmas Eve with Anders, Borman, and Lovell reading from Genesis while skimming over the moon, and the epic voyage culminating with that famous “Giant leap... Those are memories ever engrained in my mind’s eye. The face of those memories I remember most is Walter Cronkite and knowing “That’s the way it is!”.... You trusted Walter.. To me Tim Dodd in this new age of firsts and the YouTube phenomena is beginning to take on that appeal as Walter did back then. If there is a YouTuber that can represent the public eloquently, that invokes the spirit of the times, and the wonder of it all. Tim’s the guy. When he evoked my favorite voice in memory.... Contest was over... Go Tim! and We miss you Walter! And “That’s the way it is!”
Let him fulfill his destiny of bringing space down to everyday people!
